messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Ahh I see, I ll keep that in mind. Thanks alot for all the help. Fredrik
messages.messageBody:
Jim,
Ahh I see, I'll keep that in mind.
Thanks alot for all the help.
Fredrik

Jim Gilbert wrote:

>Fredrik,
>I don't think that the menuki were covered with gold foil. It again looks
>like just a thin gold wash. It doesn't take much wear to go through it. I
>don't know if it's the lighting, but both pair of menuki have an odd pink
>color to the exposed copper. I've seen that on pieces that have been
>cleaned with metal polish. I don't know what chemical causes it.
>
>Jim
>
>
>
>>Looking at the menukis again i wonder if there is a lesson to be learned
>>regarding the amount of gold foil removed. I do understand that the
>>placements of the menukis are such as they are exposed to a lot of wear,
>>but still the loss is significant. Is this always expected or could it
>>be that the gold have been poorly appliquéd?
>>I have a pair of another menuki with even more loss of gold, well only
>>on one of them. The other is probably replaced by a new made.
>>
>>http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki1.htm
>>http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki2.htm
>>
>>Fredrik
>>
>>
>>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik, I don t think that the menuki were covered with gold foil.  It again looks like just a thin gold wash.  It doesn t take much wear to go through it.  I
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik,
I don't think that the menuki were covered with gold foil. It again looks
like just a thin gold wash. It doesn't take much wear to go through it. I
don't know if it's the lighting, but both pair of menuki have an odd pink
color to the exposed copper. I've seen that on pieces that have been
cleaned with metal polish. I don't know what chemical causes it.

Jim

> Looking at the menukis again i wonder if there is a lesson to be learned
> regarding the amount of gold foil removed. I do understand that the
> placements of the menukis are such as they are exposed to a lot of wear,
> but still the loss is significant. Is this always expected or could it
> be that the gold have been poorly appliquéd?
> I have a pair of another menuki with even more loss of gold, well only
> on one of them. The other is probably replaced by a new made.
>
> http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki1.htm
> http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki2.htm
>
> Fredrik
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks a lot you two. Nice story Ron, no doubt the females will enjoy it..:) Looking at the menukis again i wonder if there is a lesson to be learned regarding
messages.messageBody:
Thanks a lot you two.
Nice story Ron, no doubt the females will enjoy it..:)

Looking at the menukis again i wonder if there is a lesson to be learned
regarding the amount of gold foil removed. I do understand that the
placements of the menukis are such as they are exposed to a lot of wear,
but still the loss is significant. Is this always expected or could it
be that the gold have been poorly appliquéd?
I have a pair of another menuki with even more loss of gold, well only
on one of them. The other is probably replaced by a new made.

http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki1.htm
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki2.htm

Fredrik

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 4/7/2005 7:14:46 P.M. Central Daylight Time, jggilbert@EARTHLINK.NET writes: The  other menuki is a sho with a side-blown flute depicted
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 4/7/2005 7:14:46 P.M. Central Daylight Time,
jggilbert@... writes:

The other menuki is a sho with a side-blown flute depicted behind it. The
sho a mouth-blown reed instrument used in bugaku/gagaku (along with that
type of flute, drums, etc.). Masks are used in bugaku, some with
exaggerated noses, but I don't know whether a tengu mask like that was used.




Hi Jim, Ron,
I was thinking of " sho ", but on second thought I think that could be a
feather fan.
I have seen woodblock prints with the tengu holding a feather fan.
I could be wrong ( most of the time it seems )

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, The other menuki is a sho with a side-blown flute depicted behind it.  The sho a mouth-blown reed instrument used in bugaku/gagaku (along with that type
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
The other menuki is a sho with a side-blown flute depicted behind it. The
sho a mouth-blown reed instrument used in bugaku/gagaku (along with that
type of flute, drums, etc.). Masks are used in bugaku, some with
exaggerated noses, but I don't know whether a tengu mask like that was used.

Several books mention that the bugaku mask depicting the shinto god
Sarutahiko no Mikoto is frequently confused with a tengu. I think he's more
of a big wide-nosed rather than long-nosed type, though.

Jim

> The
> one menuki depicts a "tengu" mask and the other (I think) a "wisk."
Somebody
> else might know the association between these. I've always like this "long
> nosed tengu" and have a mask on the wall of my sword room. Story has it
that
> if you become a "know it all" and kind of an "instant expert" with your
> swords (not wanting to study or listen to your peers) your nose will grow
> like the "long nose tengu." Neat, eh? Of course I have to explain that
story
> when a new female visitor is around, least she get the wrong impression
and
> think I'm a dirty old man.
>
> Menuki look pretty "late" but interesting.
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik - Yes, the menuki are totally different than the Mino Goto other fittings. The one menuki depicts a tengu mask and the other (I think) a wisk.
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik -

Yes, the menuki are totally different than the Mino Goto other fittings. The
one menuki depicts a "tengu" mask and the other (I think) a "wisk." Somebody
else might know the association between these. I've always like this "long
nosed tengu" and have a mask on the wall of my sword room. Story has it that
if you become a "know it all" and kind of an "instant expert" with your
swords (not wanting to study or listen to your peers) your nose will grow
like the "long nose tengu." Neat, eh? Of course I have to explain that story
when a new female visitor is around, least she get the wrong impression and
think I'm a dirty old man.

Menuki look pretty "late" but interesting.

Ron
STL

messages.msgSnippet: Jim and Ron, Oh well, thank you for making it all clear. I thought I had something valuable there for a second.:) But I had a good lesson and learned a lot
messages.messageBody:
Jim and Ron,
Oh well, thank you for making it all clear. I thought I had something
valuable there for a second.:)
But I had a good lesson and learned a lot from this.
Fredrik


Jim Gilbert wrote:

>Fredrik and Ron,
>
>These are often referred to as Nagoya-mono. It's a kind of shiiremono that
>copied Mino/Goto style. These fittings are often marketed as "Mino Goto,"
>but the quality of the materials and workmanship is not at that level of
>work.
>
>The problem is not that they have been cleaned, but that they are not made
>out of shakudo. This type of fitting is often coated with a thin black wash
>to simulate shakudo, but that is often worn away from the seppa dai. The
>nanako is more coarse than would be seen in genuine Mino or Goto work.
>Rather than using gold inlay/overlay a thin gold wash is used. Where this
>is rubbed on the high spots the underlying copper shows through. The
>quality of the carving is not at the level Mino or Goto work.
>
>As Ron says there is a continuum of this type of material ranging from very
>poor to pretty good. The distinction between lower quality Mino-bori and
>higher quality Nagoya-mono can be pretty fuzzy.
>
>I doubt that the fuchigashira and tsuba are by the same person. The details
>of the carving of the peony are quite different. They are the same type of
>work though. They're probably from the late Edo period. There are quite a
>few wakizashi mounted with this style of tosogu.
>
>Jim
>
>
>
>>Ron and readers,
>>
>>It seems like your impression has its followers. Someone on Rich Turners
>>message board agreed on Mino Goto, and they are probably made from the
>>same hand. However he also said the set had been cleaned and should be

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik and Ron, These are often referred to as Nagoya-mono.  It s a kind of shiiremono that copied Mino/Goto style.  These fittings are often marketed as
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik and Ron,

These are often referred to as Nagoya-mono. It's a kind of shiiremono that
copied Mino/Goto style. These fittings are often marketed as "Mino Goto,"
but the quality of the materials and workmanship is not at that level of
work.

The problem is not that they have been cleaned, but that they are not made
out of shakudo. This type of fitting is often coated with a thin black wash
to simulate shakudo, but that is often worn away from the seppa dai. The
nanako is more coarse than would be seen in genuine Mino or Goto work.
Rather than using gold inlay/overlay a thin gold wash is used. Where this
is rubbed on the high spots the underlying copper shows through. The
quality of the carving is not at the level Mino or Goto work.

As Ron says there is a continuum of this type of material ranging from very
poor to pretty good. The distinction between lower quality Mino-bori and
higher quality Nagoya-mono can be pretty fuzzy.

I doubt that the fuchigashira and tsuba are by the same person. The details
of the carving of the peony are quite different. They are the same type of
work though. They're probably from the late Edo period. There are quite a
few wakizashi mounted with this style of tosogu.

Jim

>
> Ron and readers,
>
> It seems like your impression has its followers. Someone on Rich Turners
> message board agreed on Mino Goto, and they are probably made from the
> same hand. However he also said the set had been cleaned and should be
> repatinated by an expert. I don’t see the damage but what do I know.:)
> I decided to take photos of the menukis as well. However they do not
> seem to match the rest of the fittings. What is your opinion on them?
>
> Here is the menukis.
> http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki2.htm
>
> Here is the rest of the fittings again.
> http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tosogu1.htm
>
> Fredrik
>
>
> Ron Hartmann wrote:
>
> >Fredrik -
> >
> >Not having the pictures in front of me at this moment, my impression
earlier was that they were the work of Mino Goto, same period. Maybe Jim
Gilbert is watching and can elaborate on this for you.
> >
> >Ron

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Ron and readers, It seems like your impression has its followers. Someone on Rich Turners message board agreed on Mino Goto, and they are probably made from
messages.messageBody:
Ron and readers,

It seems like your impression has its followers. Someone on Rich Turners
message board agreed on Mino Goto, and they are probably made from the
same hand. However he also said the set had been cleaned and should be
repatinated by an expert. I don’t see the damage but what do I know.:)
I decided to take photos of the menukis as well. However they do not
seem to match the rest of the fittings. What is your opinion on them?

Here is the menukis.
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Menuki2.htm

Here is the rest of the fittings again.
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tosogu1.htm

Fredrik


Ron Hartmann wrote:

>Fredrik -
>
>Not having the pictures in front of me at this moment, my impression earlier was that they were the work of Mino Goto, same period. Maybe Jim Gilbert is watching and can elaborate on this for you.
>
>Ron
>STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Fredrik Persson
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Thursday, April 07, 2005 2:21 AM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
>
>
> Hi,
> I'm glad you liked the fittings. :)
> Thanks alot for your oppinion Ron it's highly appriciated.
> I was told on another list that the fushi kashira might not be from the
> same school as the tsuba, What do you think?
>
> Fredrik
>
> Ron Hartmann wrote:
>
> >Hi -
> >
> >These look pretty typical so-called Mino Goto work of what I like to call average-good quality. There are some made much lower quality and then some that are a step above these. Notice the rounded punchings around the nakago-ana; your tsuba has three at top and seven at the bottom. Most of these kind have these punchings but I seem to recall most have five at the bottom, not seven. I'm not so sure if anyone has ever come up with a reliable answer as to the meaning of these punchings but certainly, these Mino-Goto works do carry them. Age? I think these are still considered middle Edo works, but correct me if I'm wrong. Your fittings do look very nice.
> >
> >Ron
> >STL
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: Fredrik Persson
> > To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> > Sent: Wednesday, April 06, 2005 2:55 AM

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik - Not having the pictures in front of me at this moment, my impression earlier was that they were the work of Mino Goto, same period. Maybe Jim Gilbert
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik -

Not having the pictures in front of me at this moment, my impression earlier was that they were the work of Mino Goto, same period. Maybe Jim Gilbert is watching and can elaborate on this for you.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Fredrik Persson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, April 07, 2005 2:21 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings


Hi,
I'm glad you liked the fittings. :)
Thanks alot for your oppinion Ron it's highly appriciated.
I was told on another list that the fushi kashira might not be from the
same school as the tsuba, What do you think?

Fredrik

Ron Hartmann wrote:

>Hi -
>
>These look pretty typical so-called Mino Goto work of what I like to call average-good quality. There are some made much lower quality and then some that are a step above these. Notice the rounded punchings around the nakago-ana; your tsuba has three at top and seven at the bottom. Most of these kind have these punchings but I seem to recall most have five at the bottom, not seven. I'm not so sure if anyone has ever come up with a reliable answer as to the meaning of these punchings but certainly, these Mino-Goto works do carry them. Age? I think these are still considered middle Edo works, but correct me if I'm wrong. Your fittings do look very nice.
>
>Ron
>STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Fredrik Persson
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Wednesday, April 06, 2005 2:55 AM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings

> school, style, technique, design and value. Please help me.
>

I'm glad you liked the fittings. :)
Thanks alot for your oppinion Ron it's highly appriciated.
I was told on another list that the fushi kashira might not be from the
same school as the tsuba, What do you think?

Fredrik

Ron Hartmann wrote:

>Hi -
>
>These look pretty typical so-called Mino Goto work of what I like to call average-good quality. There are some made much lower quality and then some that are a step above these. Notice the rounded punchings around the nakago-ana; your tsuba has three at top and seven at the bottom. Most of these kind have these punchings but I seem to recall most have five at the bottom, not seven. I'm not so sure if anyone has ever come up with a reliable answer as to the meaning of these punchings but certainly, these Mino-Goto works do carry them. Age? I think these are still considered middle Edo works, but correct me if I'm wrong. Your fittings do look very nice.
>
>Ron
>STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Hi - These look pretty typical so-called Mino Goto work of what I like to call average-good quality. There are some made much lower quality and then some that
messages.messageBody:
Hi -

These look pretty typical so-called Mino Goto work of what I like to call average-good quality. There are some made much lower quality and then some that are a step above these. Notice the rounded punchings around the nakago-ana; your tsuba has three at top and seven at the bottom. Most of these kind have these punchings but I seem to recall most have five at the bottom, not seven. I'm not so sure if anyone has ever come up with a reliable answer as to the meaning of these punchings but certainly, these Mino-Goto works do carry them. Age? I think these are still considered middle Edo works, but correct me if I'm wrong. Your fittings do look very nice.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Fredrik Persson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 06, 2005 2:55 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Help Kantei a set of fittings


Hi,
I would like to have some help with this set of fittings. They are
fitted on a Shinto wakizashi signed Bizen no Kami Sukekuni.
Unfortunately no one is signed. I would like to have opinions regarding
school, style, technique, design and value. Please help me.

http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tosogu1.htm
You can press the images for larger pictures.
Thank you,
Fredrik

messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, Many thanks for the input. I am aware of the sanjo in boston but I don t have the book and cannot find a way in on line. Any chance that you could
messages.messageBody:
Hi John,

Many thanks for the input. I am aware of the sanjo in boston but I don't
have the book and cannot find a way in on line. Any chance that you could
send me a copy of the scan of your sword or the one in boston if you have a
copy?

best regards and good luck with yours.

Roger
